instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_S0_PGOOD: What is PM_S0_PGOOD?  PM_S0_PGOOD is created when CPUVR_PGOOD and ALL_SYS_PWRGD are present and branches off to become PM_PCH_PWROK. PM_S0_PGOOD and SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD are necessary to create SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD_R: What is CPUVR_PGOOD_R? CPUVR_PGOOD_R is a signal that comes from CPU_VR_EN that is necessary along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRDGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRDGD? This is a typo of . When you see ALL_SYS_PWRDGD, assume they meant to type .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.SSD_PWR_EN: What is SSD_PWR_EN? SSD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip making the power rail for the SSD to turn on when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SSD_RESET_L: What is SSD_RESET_L? SSD_RESET_L is a signal that puts the SSD in reset mode when it is low. This means the SSD will not be accessible when this signal is asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.SSD_RESET_CONN_L: What is SSD_RESET_CONN_L? SSD_RESET_CONN_L is a signal that goes to the SSD that will put it in RESET mode which will keep it from working, when SSD_RESET_L is present. _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.11A and not turning on after a dead fly over <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Got corrosion on <RESISTOR>R7611</RESISTOR>/12. Replaced them and now stuck on 0.11A. No other corrosion on the board. No damaged traces between <RESISTOR>R7611</RESISTOR>/2 and <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
3.3/5V are present.

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> - 1.04V
<SIGNAL>PPDDR_S3_REG_L</SIGNAL> - 1.20V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG_L</SIGNAL> - 3.20V

I managed to fire it up with SMC bypass before, but now is not even initiating. Any advice?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.11A and not turning on after a dead fly over <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> voltages.
CPU core gets any voltage?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.11A and not turning on after a dead fly over <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No core voltage on CPU core

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.31V
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRDGD</SIGNAL> - 0.1V
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD_R</SIGNAL> - 3.32V
<SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK_R</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWR_PWROK</SIGNAL> - 0.1V
<SIGNAL>PM_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.43V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.11A and not turning on after a dead fly over <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you still have 1V at L7630?
If yes, check L7430, L7820 and all voltages from page 58 too.

Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and check <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> again.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.11A and not turning on after a dead fly over <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
L7630 - 1V, only coils I dont have voltage are CPU core
L7430 - 1.21
L7820 - 1.8V

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> - 1.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.32V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 3.31V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - 3.32V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.32V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.33V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5.09V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> - 1.06V


Removed <CHIP>U8150</CHIP> and turns on  <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  - 3.33V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.11A and not turning on after a dead fly over <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Still no voltage on CPU coils (without <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>)?
Post <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> voltages then.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.11A and not turning on after a dead fly over <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
got it running without <CHIP>U8150</CHIP>, remembered you mentioning that we don't need it. shall i leave it off?

Can load up now and everything seems to work ok on external drive, apart from not detecting the SSD. Tried with 2 spares and none are detected. I can load via USB and seems stable

Did PRAM reset

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD_FET_R</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.2V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.11A and not turning on after a dead fly over <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> is a redundant protection.
If the 3 power rails supervised by it are good, no need to resolder it.

Post <CHIP>U3740</CHIP> voltages.
Check all pads of SSD connector and its traces.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.11A and not turning on after a dead fly over <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3740</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>P3V3SSD_VMON</SIGNAL> - 0.99V
<SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.28V
<SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_CONN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.42V
<SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> - 3,23V

Cleaned the pads, and tried with spare SSD

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.11A and not turning on after a dead fly over <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
SSD is not detected at all in Disk Utility?

Inspect all traces and components related with J3700.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.11A and not turning on after a dead fly over <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Not Detected at all, tried another bunch of SSD and getting ? mark. Not even one deteced under Disk Utility or System Report

Cleaned the traces and rechecked for any damaged/corroded components around. None

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 0.11A and not turning on after a dead fly over <SIGNAL>P1V05S0_FB</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Try changing <CHIP>U3710</CHIP>/11.
Compare J3700's voltages/signals with good board.
